keywords: Double-crested cormorants, Caspian terns, East Sand Island, Columbia River estuary, Aerial photographs, Ground counts, Total number of nesting pairs, Productivity, Habitat use, Georeferencing.
abstract:
This method uses a combination of high-resolution aerial photographs and ground counts to estimate the number of double-crested cormorants and Caspian terns nesting on East Sand Island in the Columbia River estuary each year. The team takes photos and conducts ground counts during different stages of the birds' nesting season, including peak egg incubation for adult estimation and peak chick rearing for productivity measurement. They also use multiple ground counts to calibrate aerial survey data. By georeferencing the aerial images, they can quantify the total amount of habitat used by the birds during the nesting season. This information allows for evaluating the effectiveness of avian management actions and their impact on juvenile salmonids.

In simpler terms, this method helps accurately count the number of cormorants and terns that live on East Sand Island, which is important to assess the impact of these birds on juvenile salmonids and the need for potential management actions. The combination of aerial images and ground counts ensures an accurate and reliable estimation while also providing valuable habitat usage information.
description:
In this study, researchers employ high-resolution, georeferenced aerial photographs and ground counts to estimate the annual population of double-crested cormorants and Caspian terns residing on East Sand Island in the Columbia River estuary. The data collection process involves capturing images and conducting ground surveys at different stages during the birds' nesting season.

During the period of peak egg incubation, researchers quantify the total number of adults by gathering both aerial imagery and ground counts. These counts help determine the population size, which is crucial for assessing colony productivity.

At the onset of peak chick rearing, researchers conduct additional ground surveys to evaluate productivity â€“ the number of young produced per nesting pair. Aerial surveys are then used in conjunction with multiple ground counts to calibrate and validate the data obtained from the aerial imagery.

Georeferencing these aerial images is an essential step, as it enables researchers to measure and quantify the total amount of habitat used by the birds during the nesting season. The collected data on the number of nesting pairs (adults), productivity, and habitat use can then be utilized to assess the effectiveness of avian management actions. These actions are intended to reduce colony size and, ultimately, minimize impacts from the colony on juvenile salmonids.
